ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRE-APPROVED CHARGE AND CREDIT CARDS


    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will discourage banks and other financial institutions from issuing pre-approved charge and credit cards.

Column: 372



     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the Member that the issuance of pre-approved charge and credit cards should not be encouraged. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has sent out a circular to all card issuers in Singapore at the end of last week directing them not to issue credit or charge cards to any person unless he has applied for it in writing.

    Only one bank has actually sent out such cards. Under their scheme, pre- approved cards were mailed to selected existing cardholders who already qualify for credit and charge cards under MAS' guidelines on credit and charge cards. The pre-approved cards offer access to a range of new services but the cardholder's credit limit granted by the bank remains unchanged. Although the bank's pre-approved card scheme does not raise the cardholder's capacity to spend, such aggressive marketing of credit cards will pressure other card companies to respond by offering better credit terms and some have already done so. A proliferation of such practices will eventually lead to imprudent spending and increased defaults.

    I would like to assure the Member that the Government shares his concern and the practice of issuing pre-approved credit and charge cards has been stopped in Singapore.

PROPERTY MARKET
(Measures to stabilise)


    2. Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew asked the Minister for Finance, in view of our strong economic growth, the rapid rise in property prices and the prediction of another bull run on the stock market, what measures are being taken by the Government (i) to stabilise the property market and (ii) to avoid a convergence of these events which may lead to a "bubble economy" with its dire consequences.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, economic growth in the first half of this year was substantially above expectations and the main impetus came from strong growth in the manufacturing and transport

Column: 373

sectors which more than offset a slowdown in the finance sector. The momentum of growth in the manufacturing and transport sectors is expected to be sustained in the second half due to strong external demand arising from economic recovery in our main export markets, but the finance sector and domestic demand growth will be weak. GDP growth for the year as a whole is therefore expected to be within the range of 9-10%. This high level of growth is not expected to be sustained, however, and GDP growth in 1995 should return to a more modest 6-8% rate.

    Against this background, I see little danger of a "bubble economy" developing, nor do I see the makings of a runaway bull run on the stock market. The price-earnings ratio of our stock market currently is still in the low 20s, unlike the bubble situation in Japan in the late 1980s when its price-earnings ratio went above 50. Our financial sector is well regulated to ensure that banks and other financial institutions here are not over- exposed to the stock market.

    Interest rates are rising world-wide and this should have a moderating effect on equity markets over the next 1-2 years. The Singapore and Malaysian stock markets have stabilised after falling from last year's excesses and their current performance should better reflect the growth rates of the underlying economies.

    The increase in property prices in recent years has reflected strong demand by households, underpinned by the rapid growth in their income levels and their aspirations to upgrade. While property prices will appreciate with economic growth, the price surge over the past two years is not sustainable. In the commercial and office sector, rentals today are significantly lower than what they were when they peaked in 1990.

    The most effective way of stabilising property prices is to ensure that there is adequate supply of new housing and land for development. The Member would have noted the many announcements made by the Ministry of National Development in recent months on its plans to increase the supply of land for all

Column: 374

categories of housing. Over the past three years, MND has progressively increased the amount of State land sold for private residential development - from land for 2,500 units in 1992 to land for 4,000 units this year. This will be increased to 6,000 units next year. The potential supply of private residential units in the pipeline currently stands at 71,000. At the same time, MND has tightened up its rules on the sale of private properties to discourage speculative buying of properties. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore is also scrutinising more carefully the accounts of individuals and companies active in property transactions to ensure that appropriate taxes are paid.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew (Nominated Member): Sir, I presume that the release of more State land for residential buildings will still be done by tender. Would that not push property prices even higher?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I do not understand why the tender system should automatically push prices up if the supply is large. It is based on supply and demand. So why should the tender system push prices up by itself?

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew: Sir, would the Minister assure us that he will monitor the prices and if they continue to rise, something will be done to ensure that there will be no spiral?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I will convey the Member's request to the Minister for National Development.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, is there a floor price during the tender offer? Would you withdraw the tender, if it does not meet your minimum level?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: There is a floor price established by the Chief Valuer, below which the tender can be withdrawn, and we have done so.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Therefore, as you move the floor price up, it will actually push the price higher.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The floor price will be determined by the prevailing market situation.

TAX RELIEF FOR FOREIGN MAID LEVY FOR SINGLE WOMEN
(For caring of aged parents)


    4. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Finance whether he will allow single women who take care of their aged parents to claim tax relief for foreign maid levy.

Column: 376



     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the tax relief for foreign maid levy was introduced to specifically encourage married women to join the work force and at the same time have children. It is not meant to help all employers of foreign maids.

Singles who maintain their aged parents are allowed a tax relief of $3,500 for each dependent parent. ALLEGED BRUTALITY ON THAI NATIONAL BY OFFICERS INVESTIGATING MURDER CASE


    7. Dr Toh Keng Kiat asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether there will be an enquiry into reports of alleged brutality on a Thai national by officers investigating a case of murder.
CONFESSIONAL STATEMENTS
(Safeguards)


    8. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in view of the recent murder case implicating a Thai worker, whether he will identify the existing safeguards that are employed to ensure that confessional statements are recorded voluntarily.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, may I take Questions Nos. 7 and 8 together as they are related to the same subject?

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked whether there are safeguards to ensure that confession statements

Column: 378

given to Police are recorded voluntarily. Yes, there are safeguards to ensure that there is no abuse of Police powers in Police investigations, including the taking of statements. Let me elaborate.

    Firstly, strict criteria are in place for the selection of investigators who record statements. These officers must have proven themselves to be objective and fair in their treatment of accused persons and should have the aptitude for investigations.

    Secondly, all investigations are supervised by Chief Investigation Officers and Heads of Investigation in the Police Division, and OC of branches and Heads of Division in the CID. Investigation papers are studied carefully to ensure that the investigations are conducted in a fair and objective manner and that all statements are given voluntarily.

    Accused persons are at liberty at any time to complain of assault or ill-treatment to the authorities. In every Police lock up, there is a senior officer tasked to check the lock up routinely and record any complaints from the accused persons. The lock ups are also checked by watch officers and the station sergeant every day. They are also checked by Head, Manpower, Administration and Logistics, regularly. If a prisoner complains of assault, unfair treatment or ill-treatment, it is the duty of the officer who receives the complaint to refer it to his superior for immediate investigation.

    While in custody, the accused person can also request for medical attention and on his request will be sent for a medical examination. In addition, accused persons involved in High Court cases are subject to medical examination at Government hospitals before and after the recording of the accused's statement pertaining to the charge. Any complaint of abuse can hence be made to the doctor immediately. This is standard procedure.

    All complaints of police abuse are investigated by the Internal Investigation Section (IIS) immediately. IIS, being an independent unit in Police HQ, provides an internal check against Police abuse during investigation.

Column: 379



    As Dr Soin's question arose from the recent case of a Thai worker who was acquitted of murder by the court, let me briefly highlight some salient points concerning the case.

    The accused, Mr Somporn Chinphakdee, was charged for the murder of another Thai national, who was his room mate, at a worksite at Pasir Ris in March last year. The initial evidence against him was circumstantial. He was found alone with the deceased at the scene of the murder by his colleagues who were playing cards next door at the time. They were alerted to the scene of crime immediately after banging sounds and groans were heard. The accused fled the scene of crime before the arrival of the Police. He was also found subsequently to be in possession of the deceased's passport and gold chain. During the investigation, the accused admitted to the murder and a formal statement was recorded accordingly.

    The accused subsequently complained of having been assaulted by the Police on his chest and foot during the recording of the statement. Investigation by the Police's Internal Investigation Section, however, found no evidence to substantiate these allegations.

    About eight months after this initial complaint, Somporn further alleged to a Prison doctor that the Police had inflicted pain on him by inserting needles into his arm. This was a new allegation which the Police was not aware of until the time of the trial. The Prison doctor did not report this allegation to the Prison HQ or the Police. Somporn also did not raise it earlier at any of the four separate occasions when he was examined by doctors in relation to the recording of the statements. Why Somporn has remained silent about the needles all this while is known only to him.

    In the prosecution's case against the accused, some reliance was placed on the accused's admission to the Police. The Attorney-General has advised that where the prosecution seeks to admit in evidence

Column: 380

the confession of an accused person, the law places on the prosecution the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the confession was made voluntarily. This is a heavy burden of proof. Furthermore, section 122(5) of the Criminal Procedure Code provides, among other things, that "... the court shall refuse to admit any statement ... if the making of the statement appears to the court to have been caused by any inducement, threat or promise having inference to the charge...." In the judgment of Somporn's case, the trial judge stated that "It appeared to me that the accused had been assaulted on March 18th, 1993 whilst he was in police custody." The trial judge did not appear to have made, as it was unnecessary to do so, an express finding that the accused was, in fact, assaulted in the manner alleged.

    As the AG's Chambers has already filed notice of appeal against the acquittal of Somporn, it would not be appropriate for me, Sir, to comment further on this matter.

    Dr Toh Keng Kiat asked if there would be an enquiry into the allegation of Police abuse. As I have mentioned, all allegations of Police assault are investigated by IIS. In Somporn's case, his initial complaints were promptly looked into. In view of his latest allegation of Police assault using needles, IIS is investigating this new allegation.

    We must not let Somporn's case create a wrong impression that allegations of Police abuse are common. It is not common. Last year, for instance, the IIS investigated 94 complaints of Police abuse on suspects. This represents only 0.5% of the 18,000- 19,000 suspects arrested each year. Of these, only 14 cases were substantiated. The 16 errant officers involved have all been dealt with departmentally or even prosecuted in court. This figure represents less than 0.2% of our Police Force which totals over 10,600 officers.

    Sir, let me conclude by assuring the House that the Ministry of Home Affairs treats all allegations of Police abuse seriously. Police abuse must never be

Column: 381

condoned. If any officer is found to have abused his powers in any way, he faces disciplinary action and even prosecution where appropriate. Public confidence in the integrity and professionalism of our law enforcement agencies is high. It has taken us many years to achieve this. Let me assure this House that the Ministry of Home Affairs will not allow any black sheep to tarnish the image and integrity of any of its departments, especially the Police.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, will the Ministry of Home Affairs consider requiring the Police to use a camera during interrogation and the taking of statement from a suspect?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I am not sure whether that will solve the problem. Because even if we video tape the recording of the statement, it is still open to the accused to say that there was inducement, threat or promise, before the statement was given.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether his Ministry will take up the suggestion by a member of the public, who had been in the Police Force before and had served in the IIS, that the IIS be made an independent body?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Currently, as I have elaborated in my answer, the IIS is independent of the ground units which it is investigating. It comes directly under Police HQ. I think we have to be careful about this because it is natural to say, why not make the IIS independent. But the point is this. The Police Commissioner is given the authority over his men. What comes with this authority will be the powers to ensure that his men do their job properly. If there is any recalcitrant, that person should be punished. I think this should continue. As the commander in chief, he should have that assurance, authority and power. So the bottom line is: do we trust the integrity and the professionalism of the Commissioner of Police? We certainly do. Because if we do not trust him, then he is not the right man for the job.

    We have to see this in perspective. As I have mentioned just now, it has been

Column: 382

shown by the statistics that the IIS is doing a good job. As Mr Mike Chan himself said in the Forum page of the Straits Times, having been a former investigator, he does not doubt its integrity or professionalism. That there have been cases in the past when investigations have in fact been substantiated, shows that there is no question of cover- up. If there is any breach of rules or wrongdoing, it will be uncovered. It has been uncovered in the past. It will be uncovered in the future. And I think we should allow the IIS to continue doing its job.

    Having said this, Sir, the Ministry, of course, is concerned that the IIS should also, in the public eye, be perceived to be doing its job well. Whilst we feel that the IIS should continue to be within the Police set-up, the Ministry has, in fact, begun the process of examining to see how it can be further strengthened.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, firstly, would the Parliamentary Secretary consider, instead of making the IIS completely independent, introducing an independent component into the IIS for the public perception that he spoke of? Secondly, in view of the fact that bruises take about 24-48 hours to develop and appear, would the Parliamentary Secretary consider having a medical examination 48 hours after the confessional statement, rather than directly after giving the statement?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: The first question that the Member raises is whether or not we can introduce an independent component. I think we have to look at how the mechanics will operate. We need a unit which will continue to do its work fairly, thoroughly and efficiently. Within the IIS, the investigators are people who know what happens on the ground. In other words, they know what defalcations can take place. And that is why it is important that the input of these well-trained and well-grounded investigators is important. Ultimately, I think the input of the Police and the fact that the findings should be within the control of the Commissioner of Police is very important - to reinforce this element that he is in charge and in control.

    In serious cases where assault has been substantiated, the papers are referred to

Column: 383

the Attorney-General's Chambers. So there is a reference point and this has happened in the past. As I have mentioned just now, in a case last year, the defendant, a Police officer who was complained against, was, in fact, prosecuted. So it is not a closed door affair.

    On the second point, we are open to suggestions, but we have to weigh this very carefully. This has been an established procedure for a long time. It has worked well. As I have mentioned, it is less than 0.5% of cases which have been complained against. Out of 18,000 arrests in a year, 96 complaints have been lodged. Out of these complaints, only 14 have been substantiated out of a total Police Force of 10,600. It is less than 0.2%. I hope we can all see this in perspective. Of course, we should always be open to see how the procedures can be improved. But having used these procedures over such a long time with a proven track record, let us be careful about implementing changes. Any change must be weighed against possible problems that may arise.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon (Nominated Member): Sir, firstly, will the Parliamentary Secretary please inform the House, of the 14 cases that were substantiated, what kind of action was taken against the Police officers involved?
